itemsData.name: Gin Rickey
itemsData.about: This cocktail dates back to the 1880s, when bartender George A. Williamson made it special for one Colonel Joe Rickey.

itemsData.name: French 75
itemsData.about: The French 75 became popular stateside when it was included in The Savoy Cocktail Book of 1930.

itemsData.name: Sidecar
itemsData.about: In the earliest editions of his 1922 book Harry's ABC of Mixing Cocktails, the recipe includes cognac, triple sec, and lemon juice.

itemsData.name: Mint Julep
itemsData.about: The drink is mentioned twice in The Great Gatsby, yet pre-dates the prohibition era.

itemsData.name: Between the Sheets
itemsData.about: This cheeky drink was a favourite of Bright Young Things.

itemsData.name: The Mary Pickford
itemsData.about: Named after the 1920s movie star who co-founded United Artists with D.W. Griffith, Charlie Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks.

itemsData.name: The Last Word
itemsData.additional_ingredients: Lime juice, Green Chartreuse and Maraschino Liqueur
itemsData.about: This cocktail caught on in New York when vaudevillian Frank Fogarty (A.K.A. The Dublin Minstrel) brought its recipe with him.

itemsData.name: Ward 8
itemsData.additional_ingredients: Lemon Juice, Orange Juice, and Grenadine
itemsData.about: Named after the district in which Politician Martin M. Lomasney celebrated winning a seat in the General Court of Massachusetts.

itemsData.name: Hanky Panky
itemsData.about: This saucy cocktail was created from mixology master Ada Coleman, a well-regarded bartender at The Hotel Savoy in London.

itemsData.name: Bee's Knee's
itemsData.about: Another bathtub gin-based cocktail that came to fame in Prohibition was this sweet treat.

itemsData.name: Corpse Reviver
itemsData.about: The Corpse Reviver's cemented their place in the Prohibition era by being catalogued in the 1930 Savoy Cocktail Handbook.

itemsData.name: The South Side Fizz
itemsData.additional_ingredients: Lemon Juice, Club Soda, Mint, Syrup
itemsData.about: The preferred beverage of bootlegger Al Capone and his crew, the South Side Fizz's name is linked to Chicago's South Side, which his gang ran.
